T MRS oy s

T T i DRI RB

OMETIHEN e ST N ST T T s R T

GENERAL DESCRIPTION.

TOPOGRAPHY.

—0-05 Q00—

OUNDARTES. — The State of Maryland lies be-
tween 87° 53’ and 39° 43’ 18" North Latitude,
and Longitude 1° 58’ East, and 2° 30’ West from the
Capitol at Washington, being bounded on the north
by the State of Pennsylvania, on the east by Dela-
ware and the Atlantic Ocean, south and south-west
by Virginia, and south-west and west by West Vir-
ginia. The State’s outlines are more particularly de-
scribed as follows: the famous Mason’s and Dixon’s
line bounds on the east and north, and begins at
Cape Henlopen, the most eastern point of the At-
lantic coast (in Latitude 38° 274’ North, being about
twenty-three miles south of the point now called Cape
Henlopen), and running due west to a point midway
between the Atlantic Ocean and Chesapeake Bay;
thence by a line northerly (being 31° west of north),
tangent to a circle of twelve miles around the Court-
House at New Castle, Delaware ; thence from the
tangent point northerly, bounding on the circumfer-
ence of the circle until it intersects a line run due
north from said tangent point; and thence with this
due north line till it intersects a line run due west
from a point fifteen miles south from the city of
Philadelphia, as originally laid out. Thence with
this due west line (this is the line more particularly
styled Mason’s and Dixon’s line), to intersect a line
run due north from the farthest source of the Poto-
mac river. This last due north line, as always held in
possession by the States of Virginia and Maryland,
and lately finally accepted as the line, is not run from
the farthest source, but from the Fairfax stone at the
head of the northern or shorter branch of* the Poto-
mac. Thence due south to the Fairfax stone, and
thence by the south bank of the Potomac river to
Smith’s Point on the Chesapeake Bay (at the light-
house). From thence easterly to the most western
point of Watkin’s Point, on the eastern shore of the
Chesapeake. From this point the line should run
due east to the Ocean, but has lately been settled as
bounding on the north shore of Pocomoke Sound
and river, to the old line as found marked, and as
generally accepted in the neighborhood by titles
and otherwise, and thence on this old line to the
Atlantic. From this last point the State fronts on
the Atlantic Ocean northerly to the place of begin-
ning, enclosing an area of 10,979 square miles,
of which the Chesapeake Bay covers about 985
square miles, and other navigable waters about 1,000
miles.

The stone at the northeast corner of Maryland
having been remcved, in 1849 a revision of the
survey made by Mason and Dixon was determined
upon.

" Commissioners were appointed by the States of
Delaware, Maryland, and Pennsylvania, who, with
the aid of Colonel James D. Graham, verified in all
important points the work of their predecessors. A
slight change was made which increased by one
acre and eighty-seven one-hundredths the area of
Maryland.

FACE OF THE COUNTRY.— The surface on
both shores of Chesapeake Bay is level, and the soil
generally sandy. A range of hills enters the State
near the Susquehanna, and extends in a southwesterly
direction to the Potomac river, which it intersects

about ten miles above Washington city. This ridge
2





divides the alluvial or tide-water district from the
mountainous part of the State.

The tide-water district embraces nearly one-half
of the territory of the State, the surface being nearly
level, except in the northern part, and but slightly
elevated above the sea, and it is supposed to have
formed the bed of an ancient ocean. Beds of
marl, shell lime, and green sand abound, making
its soil highly productive, when properly cultivated.
The Atlantic coast of the ¢ Eastern Shore” has no
harbors, and is bordered throughout by a sandy
beach, from a few yards to more than a fourth of a
mile in breadth, enclosing a shallow lagoon, which,
owing to the blocking up of several passages by
which it formerly communicated with the sea, may
almost be considered an inland lake. The surface of
the eastern shore which forms part of the peninsula
lying between the Chesapeake and Delaware bays is
low and level, except in the northern part, where it
is somewhat broken and hilly.

In the northern part of Worcester County and
extending across into Delaware, is a high table-land
known as the ¢ Cypress Swamp,” far the most ex-
tensive of the swamps of the State, having an area
of about 50,000 acres. The mountainous district
occupies the strip of territory (not more than four
miles wide in its narrowest part) in the north-west
part of the State, between the Pennsylvania line and
the Potomac river. It is crossed by different ridges
of the Alleghany Mountains, bearing different local
names, such as South-east Mountain, Sugar Loaf
Mountain, Catoctin, Blue Ridge, Kittatinny, Rugged
Mountain, ete., none of which are of great elevation.
This district, which embraces the counties of Car-
roll, Frederick, Washington, Alleghany, and Gar-
rett<(proposed), so far from being wild and uninhab-
itable, containg some of the finest roads and most
desirable farms in the State, much of the region
being characterized by hills of moderate height,
whose rounded summits are covered with verdure,
and the streams that intersect them have generally
abrupt banks, with small tracts of alluvial soil. One
of the finest valleys is the one known in Pennsylva-
nia as the “Cumberland Valley,” in Maryland as
the ¢ Iagerstown Valley,” and in Virginia as the
“Shenandoah Valley.” Tt has a rolling surface and
fertile soil resting upon ¢ Trenton limestone,” which
is remarkable as containing all the great caverns in
the country. Westward of this valley is a belt from
thirty to sixty miles wide of ridges of moderate
height, with their included valleys, and the Alle-
ghany ranges are reached in the county of that name.
The mountains cross the State in long, parallel ridges,
frequently some distance apart, and interspersed with
broad level valleys, called ¢ glades,” which are nat-
ural meadows, for miles as flat as tide-water marshes,
and are covered with natural grass, without timber
or trees of any sort. The surface of the country
in this part of the State is generally rugged and
broken, and much of it is still covered with the native
forest.

RIVERS, BAYS, ETC. — The Potomac, which
constitutes the boundary between Maryland and Vir-
ginia, is formed by the north and south branches,
which unite about 20 miles south-east of Cumber-
land. It flows first north-east to Ilancock, passing
through several ridges of mountains, then pursues a
south-east direction, and receives from the right its
largest affluent, the Shenandoah, just before its pas-



sage through the Blue Ridge at Harper’s Ferry.
Flowing thence south-east to within fourteen miles
above Georgetown, it falls over the edge of the primi-
tive formation in one of the most interesting cataracts
in the U. States. The descent is about eighty feet
in one and a half miles, from thirty to forty feet of
which are in one perpendicular pitch. For some
fifty miles below Georgetown the general course of
the river is south and south-west, after which it re-
sumes its general south-easterly course, expanding
into an estuary some six or cight miles in width, and
empties into the Chesapeake Bay in about 88° North
Latitude, and 76° 10’ West Longitude. The entire
length of the Potomac is about three hundred and
fifty miles. The tide ascends to Georgetown, in the
District of Columbia, about one hundred and twenty
miles from the mouth of the river, which is navi-
gable for the largest vessels to Washington city.

Most of the streams flowing into the Potomac on
the Maryland side are small. Wicomico River and
Mattawoman Creek, in Charles Co., Anacostia River
and Rock Creek, near Washington, the Monocacy
River, in Frederick Co., and the Antietam River and
Licking Creek, in Washington Co., are the principal
ones.

The Susquehanna river enters the State from
Pennsylvania near the north-east corner, and, flow-
ing in a south-easterly direction for fifteen miles,
empties into Chesapeake Bay at Havre-de-Grace.
The main stream is about one hundred and fifty
miles long, and has very unequal breadth, at some
places exceeding a mile, and at others less than one-
fourth of a mile. It is adorned by numerous beau-
tiful islands, and the channel is frequently obstructed
by rocky rapids, which prevent navigation in low
stages of water.

The Patuxent is the longest river, lying entirely
in Maryland. It rises about eighteen miles east of
Frederick city. Flowing in a south-easterly direction,
it forms the boundary between Montgomery, Prince
George’s, and Saint Mary’s counties on the right,
and Howard, Anne Arundel, and Calvert counties
on the left, and empties by an estuary two or three
miles wide into Chesapeake Bay. The valley of this
river is about ninety miles long, and is remarkably
narrow. Small vessels ascend forty or fifty miles
from its month.

The entire waters of the State of Maryland flow
into Chesapeake Bay, except a few small streams in
the eastern part of Worcester County, which flow
into Sinepuxent and Chincoteague bays, and the
Youghiogheny river and branches, which empty into
the Monongahela and Ohio rivers.

Chesapeake, the largest bay in the United States,
enters Virginia between Cape Charles and Cape
Henry, in about Latitude 87° N., and Longitude
76° W., and extends into Maryland as far as 89°
86" N. Latitude, and 76° 8’ W. Longitude. The
length is about two hundred miles, and the breadth
from four to forty miles. The distance from Cape
Charles to Cape Henry is about twelve miles,

Chesapeake Bay is remarkable for the extreme
irregularity of its coast-line, —numerous bays and
estuaries are on either side, some of which serve as
outlets or reservoirs to the waters of the different
rivers of Maryland and Virginia, while others are
scarcely fed by any permanent stream, being nothing
more than mere arms or projections from the sea.
The depth of the bay is sufficient for the largest ships
to ascend nearly to the mouth of the Susquehanna.

5



i



A

2
i
